importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed, marking the beginning of the agreement under which Hamas was supposed to return deceased hostages.
The date when two coffins containing the remains of deceased hostages were reported to have crossed into Israel, signaling progress (or complications) in the implementation of the ceasefire deal.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe within which Hamas was required by the Trump administration’s ceasefire agreement to return all deceased hostages.

keyTakeAways: Two coffins containing the apparent remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred into Israel from Gaza by Hamas, escorted by Israeli military forces.
The Israeli military and Ministry of Health confirmed that the bodies were delivered to the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification and investigation.
This marks the 14th and 15th deceased hostages to be returned since the ceasefire deal signed on October 9, 2025.
Hamas previously returned 13 of the 28 deceased hostages, all of whom have been formally identified.
One of the earlier bodies handed over by Hamas was not identified as an Israeli hostage, leading Israeli sources to suggest a possible misidentification rather than intentional error.
Israeli intelligence has expressed concern that Hamas may not be able to locate and recover all remaining dead hostages due to the challenging conditions in Gaza.

US Vice President JD Vance emphasized that while the return of the bodies is a priority, the process is difficult and will not happen overnight, especially given that some bodies are buried under rubble.
Hamas claims it requires significant effort and special equipment to recover bodies in Gaza, reflecting the physical and logistical challenges of the recovery process.
The transfer of these two coffins occurred shortly after US Vice President JD Vance arrived in Israel, signaling the next phase of US engagement in the ceasefire implementation.
Both Hamas and Israel accused each other of ceasefire violations, highlighting ongoing tensions despite the agreement.

namedEntities.name: Israeli military
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The armed forces of Israel, responsible for border control and security operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Israeli military is central to the article as it confirms the receipt and handling of the coffins, and it oversees the identification and transportation of the remains to the forensic institute.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The primary military branch of Israel, involved in security, border control, and operations in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF played a direct role in escorting the coffins into Israel and confirming the transfer as part of the ceasefire agreement's implementation.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A domestic intelligence agency in Israel responsible for counter-terrorism and security operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA, in coordination with the IDF, issued a statement about the transfer of the coffins, indicating its role in monitoring and verifying compliance with the ceasefire terms.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant group that has been in conflict with Israel for decades.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is central to the article as it is responsible for returning the deceased hostages under the ceasefire agreement, and its actions are central to the compliance and enforcement of the deal.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The armed wing of Hamas, responsible for military operations and combat activities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al-Qassam Brigades announced the scheduled transfer of the two coffins, indicating direct involvement in the logistics and execution of the hostage return process.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international humanitarian organization responsible for the care and protection of victims of conflict.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross was involved in the custody of the coffins before they were handed over to Israeli forces, showing the role of international humanitarian actors in conflict zones.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key Israeli institution responsible for identifying human remains and conducting post-mortem investigations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The institute is where the identification and cause-of-death investigations of the two coffins are being conducted, central to the process of confirming the victims' identities.

namedEntities.name: United States (Trump administration)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government under the leadership of former President Donald Trump, which proposed the ceasefire deal.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. proposed the ceasefire agreement that set the conditions for the return of deceased hostages, making it foundational to the context of the article.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. Vice President who visited Israel to support the ceasefire implementation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance’s visit and statements underscored the U.S. role in monitoring and supporting the ceasefire, particularly regarding the return of the hostages.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli soldier whose body was among the 13 formally identified deceased hostages returned by Hamas.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Haimi’s identification marks one of the confirmed victims and serves as a concrete example of the successful identification process under the agreement.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As a reporter, Shalev contributed to the factual and timely reporting of the events, ensuring public awareness of the developments.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stockwell contributed to the reporting of the events, providing journalistic coverage of the hostage transfer.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Yosef contributed to the reporting, ensuring accurate and comprehensive coverage of the situation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli military confirmed that two coffins containing the apparent remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred into Israel from Gaza by Hamas, escorted by IDF troops. The bodies were delivered to the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification and investigation, marking the 14th and 15th confirmed deceased hostages returned since the US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed on October 9. While Hamas claimed the transfer was scheduled and required special equipment for recovery, Israeli officials expressed concern that Hamas may not be able to locate and return all remaining dead hostages due to rubble and logistical challenges. One of the earlier bodies was reportedly misidentified, indicating possible operational issues. US Vice President JD Vance emphasized the difficulty of the recovery process, stating that it will not happen overnight and that some bodies may be buried under rubble. This development follows a broader ceasefire agreement that required Hamas to return all deceased hostages within 72 hours, but the slow progress reflects ongoing tensions, accusations of violations, and the immense challenges of recovery in war-torn Gaza.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages’ Bodies Cross Into Israel
